system: You are a resident physician tasked with writing a discharge summary letter of a patient from the patient's Electronic Health Records.
user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

This is an example of discharge summary letter:
Dear ___,

You came into hospital because you were getting more short of breath and your ankles were swollen.

A heart scan, called an echocardiogram, showed that your heart was not pumping as well as it should.

We started you on water tablets called Furosemide. They will stop fluid collecting in your legs and lungs.

Please take 2 Furosemide tablets (2 x 40 mg = 80 mg) each morning and weigh yourself each morning.

If your weight drops by more than 2 kg over the week, reduce the dose to 1 tablet per day.

We have asked your GP practice to see you in about 2 weeks' time. They will take a blood test to check your kidney function.

We will see you in 6 weeks' time in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.

You will receive an appointment letter in the post.

Sincerely,
____

Dear ___,

During your recent hospitalization from February 10, 2024, to February 14, 2024, you were admitted under the care of Dr. Smith with symptoms including cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever. Upon evaluation, you were diagnosed with lobar pneumonia, unspecified organism (diagnosis code J18.1), as confirmed by a chest X-ray showing consolidation in the left lower lobe.

At the time of your admission, your vital signs included a temperature of 38.5°C, heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure at 130/85 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation at 92%. Initial laboratory investigations indicated elevated markers of inflammation with a CRP of 60 mg/L and WBC count of 12 x10^9/L. You were commenced on empirical antibiotic therapy with Amoxicillin IV, given every 8 hours, alongside Paracetamol as needed for fever management.

Throughout your hospital stay, we monitored a progressive improvement in your clinical parameters. By February 11, 2024, your temperature had decreased to 37.8°C, and your oxygen saturation improved to 94%. Encouragingly, your CRP levels decreased to 50 mg/L, prompting a slight adjustment to your antibiotic regimen to daily IV Amoxicillin and the addition of Atorvastatin 20 mg nightly for associated management. By February 12, 2024, the dose of Amoxicillin was maintained with plans to transition you to oral antibiotics as your condition stabilized further; CRP decreased to 35 mg/L, and oxygen saturation improved to 96%.

By February 13, 2024, your temperature normalized to 36.5°C, and CRP levels further decreased to 20 mg/L with a corresponding WBC count of 7 x10^9/L, indicating favorable response to treatment. During this time, your overall health improved significantly, and preparations for discharge were commenced.

You are medically stable for home discharge. You have been provided with oral Amoxicillin 250 mg to be taken daily for an additional five days to ensure complete resolution of the pneumonia. It is critical to adhere to this antibiotic regimen and complete the course as prescribed. 

For optimal postoperative care and to monitor your recovery, I would recommend a follow-up appointment with the outpatient clinic in two weeks. You will receive the corresponding appointment details soon.

Thank you for your cooperation during your hospital stay. Should you experience any new or worsening symptoms, please seek medical advice promptly.

Sincerely,

Dr. Smith
